story:
My name is L. Ruben Willis.  Here online, I am best known by the pseudonym of Tortured Cyclone. I am looking to find a way to break free from the financial constraints that have prevented me for most of my life from pursuing my love of writing.

I am in my mid-40's, with a wife who is permanently disabled and two children. Due to this, it has been necessary to work two jobs to keep my family fed, clothed, and to provide shelter and transportation for them. This has meant sacrificing my aspirations as a writer to take care of those needs.

Two years ago, my wife had a stroke. That combined with the wear and tear on my body from assorted aches and pains has brought it fully to my attention that I'm getting older. My dream of writing, if I do not pursue it, is on the verge of being lost forever.

With that in mind, I started writing more in 2013. And then I discovered Twitter. In the past year and a half, I have become one of the most prolific poets on the site, with more than 4,600 followers and still growing. There is more than enough material written there, to pull into several collections of poetry. In order to make that happen, a significant time investment of at least a couple hours a day needs to take place. A time commitment heretofore impossible while working sixty hours a week in two jobs.

To that end, I am looking at raising $10,000 to eliminate the need of a second job for at least 2015, providing the income that is currently gained from my secondary part-time job, and allowing me to make my writing a committed part-time job. I am also seeking to use funds from that goal in the following ways:

  • Purchase an up-to-date laptop computer with at least a terabyte in storage capacity, and processing ability to handle multiple tasks.
  • Purchase necessary software for the enhancement of productivity and the ability to create poetry that is paired with stock, royalty-free images. This includes the Microsoft Office 365 software package. Dragon voice-recognition software, with headset, Photoshop image software and Film editing software to create promotional videos as needed.
  • Create an online presence, through the registration of domain names, purchasing webspace for storage and web hosting and creation of a website to promote and preview my writing.
If I am not able to reach my goal, funds will be divided evenly between my family needs and technological upgrades, with web-presence being the final piece to be addressed.

As a thank you for participating, all donors will get a shout-out in the acknowledgements of my haiku eBook, which needs tweaking before being submitted as an eBook through the Amazon/Kindle store, and my Worlds of L. Ruben Willis anthology, due to be published in eBook form by the end of the year.

Other perks will include the shout out and inclusion as a Cyclone Chaser on Twitter and/or Facebook, the ability to have a personal chat with me via Voxer or Skype, and printed-on-demand, signed copies of the haiku collection and anthology.

In the past year, writing during free time, I have been able to draft and post more than 4,000 micropoems and several longer pieces, both essays, long-form poetry and prose. Having the ability to have dedicated writing time every day, combined with being able to reduce the workload upon myself should allow me to keep pushing forward with projects in the upcoming year.

Already, my blog, In the Eye of the Storm, has been nominated for the Liebster Award, which recognizes deserving small-follower count blogs. Two of my poems are included in the upcoming "Neverlasting" poetry compilation, due out in February of this year, from Fiery Verse LLC, and writing of mine has been featured on VoElla.com and wolfpublishing.com.

The financial issues have been a huge stumbling block over the years, stopping me from getting anywhere as a writer, due to the need to make sure the bills are paid and that everything gets taken care of. That's why this is so important. In order to break the financial chains that are preventing me from taking the next step, as a writer, I need your help!

Even if you can't contribute, get the word out! Read my writing on Twitter and Facebook, and comment! Take a look at the publications and websites that have featured my writing. Share here on IndieGogo.

Thank you.

TC
story_txt:
My name is L. Ruben Willis.  Here online, I am best known by the pseudonym of Tortured Cyclone. I am looking to find a way to break free from the financial constraints that have prevented me for most of my life from pursuing my love of writing.
I am in my mid-40's, with a wife who is permanently disabled and two children. Due to this, it has been necessary to work two jobs to keep my family fed, clothed, and to provide shelter and transportation for them. This has meant sacrificing my aspirations as a writer to take care of those needs.
Two years ago, my wife had a stroke. That combined with the wear and tear on my body from assorted aches and pains has brought it fully to my attention that I'm getting older. My dream of writing, if I do not pursue it, is on the verge of being lost forever.
With that in mind, I started writing more in 2013. And then I discovered Twitter. In the past year and a half, I have become one of the most prolific poets on the site, with more than 4,600 followers and still growing. There is more than enough material written there, to pull into several collections of poetry. In order to make that happen, a significant time investment of at least a couple hours a day needs to take place. A time commitment heretofore impossible while working sixty hours a week in two jobs. 
To that end, I am looking at raising $10,000 to eliminate the need of a second job for at least 2015, providing the income that is currently gained from my secondary part-time job, and allowing me to make my writing a committed part-time job. I am also seeking to use funds from that goal in the following ways:

Purchase an up-to-date laptop computer with at least a terabyte in storage capacity, and processing ability to handle multiple tasks.
Purchase necessary software for the enhancement of productivity and the ability to create poetry that is paired with stock, royalty-free images. This includes the Microsoft Office 365 software package. Dragon voice-recognition software, with headset, Photoshop image software and Film editing software to create promotional videos as needed.
Create an online presence, through the registration of domain names, purchasing webspace for storage and web hosting and creation of a website to promote and preview my writing.

Two of my poems are included in the upcoming "Neverlasting" poetry compilation, due out in February of this year, from Fiery Verse LLC, and writing of mine has been featured on VoElla.com and wolfpublishing.com.The financial issues have been a huge stumbling block over the years, stopping me from getting anywhere as a writer, due to the need to make sure the bills are paid and that everything gets taken care of. story:
Simple Guide to Create your Own Corporate Identity


"Are you a design student that would like to have a great reference book about corporative identity? Or maybe you just graduated and have no idea how to immerse in the world of freelance? Are you starting your own business but you have no idea what you want to project on your costumers? Or you want to update your image but you don't know what you want? If you said "yes" to any or all these questions then this is the ebook for you!"

The Project

I have been working as a freelancer especialized in logo design for years and I have noticed most of my clients aren't sure of what they want or what is the best for their business narrowing the window to simple cliche ideas that won't make them stand over their competition.

We are creatures that think in images, when someone mentions the name of a brand, the first thing that comes to our mind it's the logo, the icon, the stylish text or the product that we recognize with the name. In a World full of powerful names we need creative and clever concepts that will make us stand on top of the crowd.
"There are three responses to a piece of design – yes, no, and WOW! Wow is the one to aim for."
Milton Glaser
I want to create a guide that will be useful for both designers and people not related to the field to understand how to create a corporate identity. It will include concepts like:

  • The different types of logos and how to choose the best one.
  • Theory of the emotional meaning behind shapes and colors and how to use them to your advantage.
  • The different types of tipographic families and how to choose the best one.
  • A step by step guide of how to design a logo starting from the concept and the making on Illustrator CS6 using my own logo as example.

How can you Help

For me to bring this ebook to life I need your help, your generous funding will help me get things started.

The $2000 is to cover the costs of producing the book. To keep the costs to the minimum, it will be made in digital format.

The Impact

I can't make this book a reality without your help. With your funding I can work on a deeper and more detailed explanation that contains every single detail and tip from my experience.

story:
I Love You This Mush! is a one-of-a-kind engaging children's book series. Set in Alaska, this 12 book series features the adventures of ten seemingly misfit dogs and how the love they received from their musher, Radio, helped mold them into more than just a champion racing team.

Between the lines of these captivating and heartwarming stories, this truly important children's book series works to foster a child's positive self worth making the value of these books is far more than entertainment and developing reading skills.

 Through these stories children learn that, just as each misfit dog is "special, valuable, and loved...no matter what", they are too - regardless of their physical limitations, skills, appearance, IQ, family dysfunction, loneliness, or whatever else might be impacting their sense of self or safety!

  • The series includes 12 books (ages 7-13); one book is released and delivered each month for an entire year! The first book includes stories of all ten dogs, books 2-11 feature each individual dog's story, and book 12 features the dogs racing (for life and death!) 
  • Books are available in both electronic form (pdf or Kindle) and as paperback books delivered via USPS.
  •  Books 2-11 will also be delivered with the pocket-sized "Mushy Plushy" dog featured in that specific book.  
  • These books strategically leverage a child's natural affinity for animals; children recognize themselves in one or more of the ten dog archetypes and connect with the message that, like Radio's dogs, they too are "worthy, special, valued, and loved right where they are - no matter what!"
(Radio and some of the dogs featured in the series).


The first book in the series (as well as the series itself) is titled I Love You This Mush!  In it, musher Radio introduces his dogs to children who have come to visit his kennel. As he does, he tells a fascinating story about each dog and why their quirky traits are the very things that make them valuable to his team...it's 10 mini-adventure stories in a single book and children reading the book immediately see themselves in one of the ten dogs.

The series continues with 11 more books. Ten feature an individual dog's tale of adventure and the final book features Radio and the entire team on the trail to Nome. (Titles subject to change).

Book 1: I Love You This Mush! 

Book 2: Avalanche Ranch

Book 3: Mystery at an Arctic Ice Hotel 

Book 4: Blizzard!

Book 5: Indie Overboard

Book 6: Arctic Thunder

Book 7: Suri’s Secrets 

Book 8: The Blue Ice Cave 

Book 9: Treasure at Snowflake Camp

Book 10: Snowbound!

Book 11: No Place for a Dog

Book 12: Nome Sweet Nome!



Crowdfunding TAKES A VILLAGE and it only works when enough people care enough to back the project and then get behind it passionately and share and endorse the project to get others involved also - it is HARD WORK! 
On average, only 4% of people who click on a crowdfunding campaign will back it; doing all the math based on crowdfunding statistics, that means we need to get over 15,000 to actually click into this campaign (not just hear about it) in only 45 days! HELP!

Funds will be used for:

  • Illustrating the 12 book series
  • Cover designs
  • Writing, editing, and copyrighting
  • ISBN numbers and barcodes
  • Printing and shipping
  • Photographs or illustrations for the read-aloud book 
  • Services of a publishing consultant (as needed)
  • Pocket-sized "Mushy-Plushy" production
  • Administrative assistance that allows the I Love You This Mush! franchise to create a sustainable business model Dario's Legacy to continue it's mission long-term
NOTE:
If you want to back the project but do not want any perks, NO problem - you just let input the amount you want to back and it will ask you if you want a perk or not. Easy Peasy!

And, although backing levels with perks are set, you can back this project at any level and will still receive the associated perks for that level.

 

The first book in the series is 99% baked and in final editing. Final completion date coincides with the end of this campaign since perks include the opportunity to name the children featured in the books as well as the opportunity for children (or adults) to illustrate the inside cover page for one (each) of the 12 books. 
Check out the Perks section (to the right) for details on these opportunities! 

Books 2-12 have all story lines developed and are in various phases of writing, editing, and illustration. A pocket-sized "Mushy Plushy" for each dog is also in prototype phase and the plan is for each to be delivered along with it's accompanying book. (The final funding level of this campaign will determine if the Mushy Plushies will be included as a bonus for backers of this campaign).




No campaign succeeds without the help of many, many people who really care about making it happen; people (like you I hope!) who will jump in, back the project, and even if just for five minutes a week - spread the word to others and keep encouraging them to do the same.

Whatever you will do is genuinely appreciated and will make a difference! Not just to the campaign but to the children who will be reached through the stories and through the Steward of Light program (an organization for reaching children of abuse and where profits are donated in honor of Dario Martinez).

Here are a few ideas to get you started.

  • Email every teacher, principal, child psychologist, councilor, or other adult who works closely with children
  • Let every grandparent or parent know about this project -please! This is the IDEAL gift for a grandparent (or other relative) to give to their grandkids!
  • Talk to, email, or post on the page of any media personality, blogger, or anyone else you know who has a "following" and will help spread the word about I Love You This Mush!
  • If you blog - please blog on behalf of this project giving it your endorsement 
  • Email everyone you know with a young child or a "tween" who is having issues with self-esteem or bullying...let them know this series exists and it's there for their child, foster child, grandchild, etc.
  • Share on your Facebook, Google+, Twitter, Pinterest, & other social sites...please help spread the word far and wide!
  • You can copy and paste the link to this page (the url above) in an email or text to everyone on you list in probably less than 2 minutes, PLEASE do! :D
To learn more about the importance of this campaign please visit: DariosLegacy.com 

The photo below is the late Dario Martinez; this series was inspired by and dedicated to Dario. He's shown here with his Zion, sharin' the love in a blue ice cave.

(For photo credit, please contact us via Dario's Legacy).


*International Shipping Details

Domestic shipping is included in all perks. If you would like us to ship the perks outside of the U.S. please add the following  amount. You can add it as an additional donation on the screen where you enter your shipping address. THANK YOU!

First Book in Series
 (Perk levels: $25, $100, $200)

 $5
Book Series & Mushy Plushies
(Perk levels: $350, $1000, $1500)
 $75

story:
Nick Banner 

He's just your average foster kid who's lived his life within the often times disfunctional system. He just wants a normal life, he just wants to worry about normal things kids worry about like getting to the summer's hottest party. But on his 17th birthday, Nick's life decides to take him on an unexpected adventure. Follow along as Nick's world is turned upside down, as he battles and ancient evil and comes to terms with just who he is in the world. 

MM BEEMAN

MM Beeman is not your average youth fiction writer. He's on a mission to bring some adventure into the reading world for those who mostly, hate reading. His stories involve characters who battle to find the  path of right in a world and a life where everything seems wrong. 

MM has worked with those who are called 'disenfranchised' or 'at-risk' youth for over 10 years. What he likes about them is their potential, their veracity, their gumption. What he strives to achieve is to write stories that provide the reader moral and spiritual insights that are often found lacking in the society of today, while presenting them in a unique and entertaining manner. 

MM's unique experiences in childhood gave him a heart for kids who are often misunderstood in society. Individuals who have been given less and who often have to deal with more. For MM, writing is his outlet to both fulfill a calling he has for evangelism, and to show kids that there really are people out there who care about them. One of the goals that MM has in this book series is to network with programs and churches who have a heart to meet needs of foster kids and at-risk youth. The primary goal if this series is to to open up doors of evangelism and mentoring, while understanding that creating captivating characters is the lynch pin to accomplishing this. 

The Impact

The impact that art has on our society and especially our youth is one that lasts. Hours and hours of entertainment, video games, movies, comic books - they take up residence in our lives. The younger generation uses these outlets to learn, to grow, and to grapple with concepts that come their way. Using fiction as a way to portray positive messages in the lives of those who need it is of vital importance in our time. As an evangelistic approach, using fiction enables kids to envision them as part of the story. What kind of decisions can we make, who is there for them, who can help me? These are things MM wants to stir in readers, even grown ups! The power of a good bad vs. evil story can do just that. Will you help us!?

Risks & Challenges

MM Beeman is a break out writer. Talent is truly there, he promises! The risk is that this is a new venture for him. Reaching an audience as an introvert is quite a challenge. If you can help by sharing this campaign, the reward WILL start overtaking the risk. More adventures are brewing, you don't want to keep them holed up in the cauldron of a timid artist now do you?

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Do you have a church or organization that could use a guest speaker to do a reading? Or to talk about the challenges kids are facing today? How they can turn to Jesus for help?
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Message, comment and email this timid artist, this MM Beeman. Tell him how he is blessing you, or where he can help! This is the heart of why he is doing this, to help encourage those in hard times.

story:
Hi!

I am 29, my sister is 26 and we both suffer from a debilitating and progressive chronic illness that killed our mother. It's called Vascular EDS and our problems have a broad spectrum - mobility problems, lots of pain, unrelenting fatigue, gastric issues and a massively vulnerable vascular system. These factors all contribute to a compromised immune system - so we live a pretty miserable existence.

My boyfriend and our father are willing to support us - and we all want to live together in one house so that we can both have the care we need, whilst the home is maintained in as economical way as possible (shared chores, help on hand for us and as small a monetary footprint as possible). At the moment we all live separate to each other and too far away from each other to provide daily support.

My sister and I are forced to live isolated and in solitude, unable to maintain our own homes properly because we're not fit enough to get to each other or into town, we can't afford assistance at home or transport and/or to partake in social activities that would alleviate some of our misery... we cannot afford the rental price of a place large enough to house us all (and most landlords will only accept couples and/or family units - not the unique mix we are looking to implement)

We have no savings, as the cost of looking after us up until now and getting to and from our appointments alongside every day standard living costs have always kept us pretty much at our financial limit.

Our unique situation allows us to receive disabilty aid, but our associated income is too high for us to receive further government aid, but it is not enough for us to live sustainably on.

So what am I looking for?

I'm throwing my dignity to the wind and reaching out for help - £250k would buy me a house, anything above £60k will get me an affordable mortgage - with that money not only would we have the living environment that would greatly improve our quality of life, but we may indeed also be able to afford a health regime (gym/physio/paleative care) and a retrofitted car to share between us in the near future, which could actually make all the difference between managing and LIVING .

This really is a cry into the abyss and I am no more deserving than the next person, but my granny always told me that there are people out there who are looking to do good things and if I can reach just 25,000 willing to give £10 each.....then our lives could be changed for the better forever - that's a chance I'm willing to sacrifice my dignity for.
story_txt: Hi!I am 29, my sister is 26 and we both suffer from a debilitating and progressive chronic illness that killed our mother. It's called Vascular EDS and our problems have a broad spectrum - mobility problems, lots of pain, unrelenting fatigue, gastric issues and a massively vulnerable vascular system. These factors all contribute to a compromised immune system - so we live a pretty miserable existence.My boyfriend and our father are willing to support us - and we all want to live together in one house so that we can both have the care we need, whilst the home is maintained in as economical way as possible (shared chores, help on hand for us and as small a monetary footprint as possible). At the moment we all live separate to each other and too far away from each other to provide daily support. My sister and I are forced to live isolated and in solitude, unable to maintain our own homes properly because we're not fit enough to get to each other or into town, we can't afford assistance at home or transport and/or to partake in social activities that would alleviate some of our misery... we cannot afford the rental price of a place large enough to house us all (and most landlords will only accept couples and/or family units - not the unique mix we are looking to implement)We have no savings, as the cost of looking after us up until now and getting to and from our appointments alongside every day standard living costs have always kept us pretty much at our financial limit.Our unique situation allows us to receive disabilty aid, but our associated income is too high for us to receive further government aid, but it is not enough for us to live sustainably on. So what am I looking for?I'm throwing my dignity to the wind and reaching out for help - £250k would buy me a house, anything above £60k will get me an affordable mortgage - with that money not only would we have the living environment that would greatly improve our quality of life, but we may indeed also be able to afford a health regime (gym/physio/paleative care) and a retrofitted car to share between us in the near future, which could actually make all the difference between managing and LIVING . This really is a cry into the abyss and I am no more deserving than the next person, but my granny always told me that there are people out there who are looking to do good things and if I can reach just 25,000 willing to give £10 each.....then our lives could be changed for the better forever - that's a chance I'm willing to sacrifice my dignity for.

story:
Short Summary

A few short years ago, I couldn’t run the length of 3 houses in my neighborhood. I was over 40, over weight and over whelmed about how to get off the path I found myself on. In the time since, I have 7 marathons, 22 half marathons and 4 half ironman distance races under my feet.

Hi, my name is Leigh Underwood and I am A Most Unlikely Athlete. My journey started with a volunteer afternoon, a few supporting friends and something affectionately known as slacker mail. Along the way I compiled my experiences into a series of short stories that hopefully inspire, usually amuse and frequently mortify. Above all else they humanize what can be a daunting process to start especially later in life.

I share my journey in hopes of encouraging others to move more than the day before. Because that is all it took to get me started. With each additional step I , I became a healthier and happier person from the inside out. 

What We Need & What You Get

That is where this campaign comes in. I have written four books in a series entitled “A Most Unlikely Athlete – Short Stories to Inspire, Amuse and Mortify”.   
Writing is the easy part. The hard part is navigating the maze of the publishing and marketing options. 

I knew if I could get into shape ANYONE could so much - I self-published the first in the series. Information about it is available on www.amostunlikelyathlete.com. 

That is where my wallet dried up. To get the remaining three to the light of day requires your help. 

This particular campaign is for the cover design, editing, publishing and marketing of the second book in the series, "Fitness Fables, Funnies & Favorite Things". The financial need to make that happen is $4,000 USD.

There are three ways you can help me.

First, you can review the contribution level incentives outlined in the Perks section and make a selection that is right for you.

Second, you can share this message with family, friends and coworkers.

Third, you can purchase the first bookin the series already available.

Whatever you contribution, thank you from the bottom of my heart for helping me get this to market. 

Together we can help someone else discover their own unlikely.

The Impact

We are living longer lives with each generation. We need to be as healthy as possible for as long as possible. I came from a generation and/or maybe just area (rural Southern small town) where we did not have access to all the team sports available today. Healthy eating was considered leaving extra salt off your fried chicken and  gravy.

I got to my 40's before I did anything about it. I'm proof that you can start from below zero at any age and stage of life and still make a lasting impact. 

Since I started this, my blood pressure and cholesterol are in normal ranges. I am finally out of the body fat percentage of being obese. Even though I am still a work in progress, I feel better, stronger, healthier overall with each day that passes.

Risks & Challenges

I am a Project Manager by trade. As such I understand the concept of risk and challenges and mitigating them well in advance. 

While, every project has risk, this one is a low risk project. The books are already written and ready to go. The risk comes in if I do not achieve full funding. I will mitigate that by pursuing alternative means to raise needed funds. This will be a longer process in time to market. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Funding is only one need for this campaign. The other, and equally important is sharing the message. If you aren't in a position to contribute financially but this still speaks to you, you can still help. 

You can do that by sharing this via the Indiegogo tools, Facebook, Twitter, in email to family, friends, coworkers.

Whatever you contribution, thank you!

story:
Put money into the wallets of hard-working new and emerging writers and artists!

The Tishman Review believes in paying the poets, writers and artists for the pieces we publish in our quarterly literary journal and that’s where you come in.

Maura and Jennifer started The Tishman Review to BE DIFFERENT! They’ve been using their own money and the generous donation from Jennifer’s Mom to get them started. All of the staff at TTR volunteer all of their hours because they are passionate about our mission to publish stellar poetry, fiction, art and creative nonfiction.

Tishman Review is produced in three different formats: PDF, e-book and print-on-demand. TTR believes that by giving authors space for their words, the existential function of literature is honored and the journal’s readers’ lives are enhanced.

How is TTR different from all the other literary magazines:

1)  We pay our contributors semi-professional rates.

2)  We read blind. This means we cannot see the writer’s biography with previous publishing credits until after we have decided to accept or decline. We judge the piece solely on its words. It’s all about the words.

3)  We produce the magazine in three different formats: viewable online for free, e-book and print-on-demand. This ensures that everyone can read the magazine. And, if someone wants something to hold in their hands, they can order a print copy.

4)  About half of all submissions received at TTR get a personal response from our editors. Plus, if a submitter chooses an expedited response they are guaranteed to get editorial feedback. We know how much work goes into each piece submitted to us and we do our best to offer not only encouragement but constructive feedback.

5)  We strive to interact with everyone who crosses TTR’s path with respect, honoring their contribution, whether with our generous benefactors, our volunteer staff, or the artists and writers that submit to us.

6)  We ask for revisions! When a piece has promise, we will ask the writer if they are interested in working with us on revising the piece. Sometimes, this works out and when it does, the piece is happily accepted. This gives writers a fair chance in the extremely competitive world of literary journals.

7)  We charge a submission fee to cover our Submittable costs, website fees, and other costs of hosting an online version and producing a layout suitable for a print issue. BUT, we also host free submissions days monthly, so that all writers can submit no matter their economic status.

Our first tickler issue, launched on January 15, 2015, has been an amazing success. Over 1,200 people have opened the online version of the magazine to read it. Our April issue will be our first full-length, from the submission pile, issue and will be full of stellar fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, art and photography.

Who are the artists and writers your money will go toward?

Artists who work hard all day as servers in restaurants to pay their way through college, taking their photographs on their time off. Writers who stay home with their children, write during naps and live on one income. Poets who shuffle together enough money to pay the rent by teaching a class here or a class there and then work nights tending bar, all so they can commit themselves to their craft. Essayists who teach elementary school by day and write by night, sending their MFA student loan payments in on a monthly basis.

This is the literary world as it’s become in our challenging economy. Sometimes our own contributors return their payments to TTR as a way of supporting the many new and emerging contributors who struggle to make ends meet.

Won’t you join us in making our first ever IndieGoGo campaign a success?

Without the support of generous donors, such as you, TTR cannot accomplish all of its goals. 

The next step we must take is to file for 501(c)(3) status and this costs $850.00.

We have website hosting fees, banking fees, a yearly fee to use Submittable (in addition to what they take out of the submission fees) and office expenses. Most calls for submissions are paid advertisements, but we must put these calls out to writers to solicit submissions. There are some costs in producing the magazine in three different formats; though we work tirelessly to keep these as low as possible.  But primarily, contributor payments run us around $1,000.00 an issue.

We will forever be grateful to you if you can make a donation. Thank you!

We have some awesome perks for you. Copies of TTR, grocery tote bags, eco-friendly notebooks with pens, advertising space in our journal, critiques from our editors!

And if you can’t send any money our way, you can help by spreading the word, asking those who can, to consider making our campaign a success.

As ever, thank you for your generous support of TTR! And, we hope you enjoy reading our journal.

The Tishman Review is incorporated as a nonprofit in the state of Michigan and is in the process of applying for 501(c)(3) status from the Internal Revenue Service.  At this time, however, donations to TTR are not considered tax-deductible.

story:
It sounds bad. And so sad. And like it would kill a bull. But it's ok. I'm ok. My mom is ok. Our relationship (remarkably!) is ok. It's sad. But it's ok. And it's mine.

I was born into shame. I feel certain it was the first feeling my mother felt when she found out she was pregnant with me and the first feeling she felt when I came out brown instead of white; indicating her worst fears were true. The man standing next to her in the delivery room, 18 years her senior was not the father of this baby. Shame. I hold shame around the weeks and months following my late husband’s accident. I was called stoic and strong, but it felt like, “you aren’t sad enough.” I had a business to run and bills to pay…so many bills. It didn't matter that at times I thought the grief would overtake me, and that felt ok. Shame. Shame around the fact that I do not know who my biological father is. That to be honest, no one does right now. We have options. And I am going to get answers. Shame. Shame around the fact that I have always wanted to be a writer, traveling the world and sharing my experiences. Who am I to deserve the life I’ve dreamt about since I was a little girl? 80,000 Indian children go missing every year, I've held them in my arms... but I want to travel and write. Shame.  

Full disclosure that overall I had a very “normal” and happy childhood, but this shame comes up when I’m doing serious self-reflecting. I have a super high-energy, happy demeanor and I am so blessed to be showered with love from my friends and family; however, that does not take away from my shame and the very tragic events of my life that I feel are worth a deeper discovery. 

People have told me for years to ask if there was ever anything they could do. So, I’m asking. The resources I have most readily available to me are my writing skills (thanks OU), some people who believe in those skills, my story, and me, which is enough to provide start-up money. 

The first time I thought about writing my story was when I applied to The E.W. Scripps School of Journalism at Ohio University. I’ve always loved to write. I feel a calling to write a memoir/novel/screenplay and I need the time to write the manuscript. I may fail. Maybe no publishers will be interested and I'll self-publish. My writing may suck; my story unoriginal. Or I might find that I don’t want the self-actualization and account of this book and bail three quarters of the way through. Let me apologize in advance for that, but I don't foresee that happening.  It will be a work in progress; changing and evolving. If you don’t care about that and would like to contribute to the pipe dream I have then I greatly, greatly appreciate your support and manifest that gratitude in the form of memoir!

In facing my shame and the honest account of the first quarter century of my life, I hope to shine light on it and turn that shame into owning who I am and the life of my dreams. I’m willing to ask people to help me achieve it because I want to achieve it that badly. 

I read Jen Sincero’s You Are A Badass last October and she said something that really resonated with me. (I’m going to botch the story, so go buy the book yourself. It's worth it!) She asked, “how badly do you really want what you say you want?” If you want to travel the world badly enough you’ll go to the airport with a sign that says, “accepting one way ticket anywhere” and you’ll wait. This is my sign. I'm finding my light. I know writing will help. I know that light creates more light and writing is the best way for me to share mine.

I'm asking for $2,500 because that will allow me the time to focus on my writing and ideally have a manuscript ready in 3-6 months. For every gift of $50 you will receive a free copy of the book (either in digital or print format depending on publisher interest). Gifts of all sizes are incredibly appreciated. Thank you for believing in my story and the benefit it may have for myself and others. If I don't reach the goal, I'll use what fund I do have to still try and write enough to send to an editor and still eat every day. Haha!

This project is near and dear to my heart. It feels like the potential I have been asked to fulfill. I hope the value added is for every person young and old, regardless of gender to see someone risk a lot (sharing their shameful story, asking for money to help achieve a dream...scary stuff) and say out loud that, if no one else, I at least know that I am deserving. And in seeing someone else do it they too will know they are deserving of working hard and asking for help when they need it in order to achieve fulfillment during their time on Earth. A happy world is a world full of happy people.

My biggest hurdles in this endeavor are going to be sharing the deepest and darkest parts of myself, my story, and my past. Stories that could bring up pain and uncomfortable emotions for my entire family…that's why they live in Ohio and I'm doing this in Oregon. Haha! No, I know this is the time to share this story and the motivation of being accountable to other people who are invested in my writing will be my greatest gift in overcoming any hurdles.

If you aren't interested in giving, please share my story with anyone who's message it may benefit. To be of service is my life's greatest goal and I know this is how I can do it to the best of my ability.

story:
Thoughts in Silence 

A dream project, I wanted my upcoming book to be a collectible, a reader’s delight – to traverse along with.

Thoughts happen in silence, Silence sings.

The book is a compilation of 49 poems written the last 3 years. Why 49? A thought is never complete, silences is infinite. Completion is relative and our thoughts are relative. An extension of this thought process brought the number 49 in my mind, and it so happened that when I counted the poems, it was 49!

The poems are based on moments, thoughts that I lived, moments that triggered thoughts, thoughts that took shape in silence. The poems live Nature, loneliness, Motherhood, Love, Remembrance, Travel, Live in, Sensual, nostalgia, Free life.

Thus the idea of book was born.

A photo journalist friend of mine was generous enough to allow me to use his photograph for Book Cover. A person, whose legacy is an inspiration and I respect, agreed to write foreword. It was a great honor. This motivated and inspired me to scale new heights to dream further.  What followed was me reaching out to my photo journalist, professional photographers and techies who love photography and share my thought about the book. I requested if I could use their photos which would tell a story, which would take us on a travel within mind. They loved the idea. Photos flooded and all photos were lovely!

I approached my cousin for help to choose and sort the photos, and he chose 8 photos from 300 odd photos! I don’t have words to thank him! Now I have shared another hundreds with him!

Two of my friends help me with the editing part so that the book does not end up with errors J

Life is Beautiful and I am indebted!

I look forward to your support to make this collective dream a reality.

Lets Team up!

Eswar Anandan
story_txt:
Thoughts in Silence 
A dream project, I wanted my upcoming book to be a collectible, a reader’s delight – to traverse along with.
Thoughts happen in silence, Silence sings.
The book is a compilation of 49 poems written the last 3 years. Why 49? A thought is never complete, silences is infinite. Completion is relative and our thoughts are relative. An extension of this thought process brought the number 49 in my mind, and it so happened that when I counted the poems, it was 49!
The poems are based on moments, thoughts that I lived, moments that triggered thoughts, thoughts that took shape in silence. The poems live Nature, loneliness, Motherhood, Love, Remembrance, Travel, Live in, Sensual, nostalgia, Free life.
Thus the idea of book was born.
A photo journalist friend of mine was generous enough to allow me to use his photograph for Book Cover. A person, whose legacy is an inspiration and I respect, agreed to write foreword. It was a great honor. This motivated and inspired me to scale new heights to dream further.  What followed was me reaching out to my photo journalist, professional photographers and techies who love photography and share my thought about the book. I requested if I could use their photos which would tell a story, which would take us on a travel within mind. They loved the idea. Photos flooded and all photos were lovely!
I approached my cousin for help to choose and sort the photos, and he chose 8 photos from 300 odd photos! I don’t have words to thank him! Now I have shared another hundreds with him!
Two of my friends help me with the editing part so that the book does not end up with errors J
Life is Beautiful and I am indebted!
I look forward to your support to make this collective dream a reality.
Lets Team up!
Eswar Anandan

story:
Heavy Music Artwork launches world’s first and only metal and rock art magazine - Issue 4 pre-sell: LEGACY

Heavy Music Artwork forth installation. The endless, the unageing, the timeless. This issue we look at the enduring legacy of rock and metal. Featuring: Kiss, Def Leppard, Disturbed, Korn, Sepultura 'Roots', Annihilator, Black Star Riders, Immolation, Six Feet Under, Dave McKean, Ken Kelly, Andreas Marschall, Phil Lawvere, Gerald Scarfe, Par Olofsson, Arik Roper, Alan E. Brown and more.

All Heavy Music Artwork print editions specifications

  • Printed on high-quality uncoated stock, which gives texture and earthy feel
  • Ethically sourced and FSC approved and using vegetable based inks
  • Limited edition of 666 units hand numbered and stamp embossed
  • Perfect PUR binding on 250gsm (cover) Offset Paper
  • 100 pages (approx)
  • 3000 Copies standard edition printed to fulfill distribution commitments
  • 1000 Copies for this campaign which include the 666 limited editions

Heavy Music Artwork Portraits Book details and specifications

This year we are celebrating 5 years in operation and we decided to release a book on heavy metal portrait photography. All photos have been taken by our photographers over the last five years. To accompany the book we have also included critiques and insights by The National Portrait Gallery of Canada and The Scottish National Portrait Gallery exclusively to accompany the book. Plus high profile guest photographers.

  • Finished size 260mm deep x 210mm wide portrait
  • Printed on 200 full color and black & white silk pages
  • Beautifully designed and curated
  • Soft velvet feel hard back cover

Some of the artists included in the book are Ghost, Anthrax, Deez Nuts, Opeth, Wardruna, Neurosis, Steel Panther, Devilment (Dani Filth), Belphegor, Possessed, Orange Goblin, Alter Bridge, Napalm Death, Obituary, Carcass, Prong, Lordi, Corrosion of Conformity, Doyle, Epica, Powerwolf, Fleshgod Apocalypse, Insomnium, Kreator, Nashville Pussy, Abbath, Primordial, Soulfly, King Parrot, Behemoth, Abbath, Baroness, Overkill, Butcher Babies, King Diamond, Testament and more. Full list coming soon.

Arte Divina T-Shirt

Featured perk content - First 4 issues book and more

What We Need

Your contribution will help Heavy Music Artwork launch the 3rd magazine and secure future releases, and is also a way to pre-sell before it hits the stores around the word. As with the first two campaigns, we are looking to raise a base of £5,000. This will get the project off the ground and will give some breathing room to get issue 4 going.

This is an estimate of our costs and where the funds will go towards

  • 30% Production costs
  • 20% Marketing
  • 18% Overheads
  • 25% Printing costs
  • 7% Campaign fees

Our awesome perks

Our perks are simple and include something for everyone, please see side panel. Perks images are also displayed in the gallery.

Vision & Mission

  • Provide the heavy metal community and industry with outstanding resources, material, information, news, and updates
  • Promote graphic artists, music artists, record labels and agencies through interviews, biographies, artworks and in-depth profiles
  • Entice people to explore and experience life within the arts
  • Examine through music, art, and literature all aspects of the human condition

The Impact

  • Your impact will not only benefit us as a publisher but the artists and the metal community as whole
  • We are dedicated to placing the magazine in places where you wouldn't normally see a metal magazine like art galleries and museums
  • Our work has helped young artists getting the attention they deserve as well as getting paid jobs from bands
  • Heavy metal is one of the most relevant and influential art forms and it must be celebrated as such, Heavy Music Artwork is the first to make this statement

Since our launch www.heavymusicartwork.com has enjoyed great popularity, reaching nearly 1 million page views, and 25,000+ monthly visitors. Promoted via all HMA social networks 80K+ Followers. Newsletter to 5K HMA email subscribers.

Labels and PRs that helped us along the way

Agonia Records, Century Media, Debemur Morti Productions, Earache, Indie Recordings, Lifeforce Records, Lion Music, Mascot Group, Massacre Records, Metal Blade, Napalm Records, Nuclear Blast, Peaceville, Pitch Black Records, Relapse, Season of Mist, Snapper Music, Southern Lord, SPV, Universal, Spinefarm, Warner Music, Svart Records.

Adrenaline PR, Asher Media, Audacious PR, Clawhammer PR, Cosa Nostra, Devil PR, Dewar PR, Domino Media, Duff Press, Earsplit, Factory Music, Fly PR, Future PR, I Like Press, Noble PR, Noise Cartel, Old Empire, Perfect Storm PR, Pioneer Music Press, Publicity PR, Rarely Unable, Red Sand PR, Savage Gringo, Scream Promotion, Silverblack, Stampede Press, Speakeasy PR, Stereo Sanctity, Team All About The Music, Visible Noise, Wilful Publicity and Work Hard PR.

What are the risks?

As with any project, there are risks involved in releasing a publication. We might not be able to deliver the end product on time, or we might run into problems with the printing and shipping. Our team has over 15 years in delivering creative projects of all sizes and shapes. The 1st issue is ready to go to print, so any problems are very unlikely.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: Ask your fellow metal head to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Please share and make the world know that metal is art in all its forms.

story:
Hello!

Did you know there are more than 3 billion people using messaging applications —1 billion on Facebook alone?

My name is Kerry Gardiner and Bookbot Bob and Bookbot Bill are the product of my passion for self-publishing. I have been publishing crime fiction since 2014 after graduating from university with a degree in law. Once I realised how useless that actually was for a 'middle-aged' single mother, I turned my hand to writing - and I've never been happier. 

The Bots appeared one night knocking on my sub-conscious demanding to be brought to life. Much like the characters in my books as it happens. Self-publishing is hard, and getting harder all the time. There are opportunities out there to promote your work but they are often expensive, and ineffective. People are growing more resistant to giving out their email addresses (who can blame them) and it is a constant battle to stand out from the noise of a crowded inbox. 

The aim of my campaign is twofold. Firstly, to raise money for advertising to gain more subscribers - thus increasing the return on investment for the authors using the service - and to develop an app. Facebook is the first major platform to allow the use of chatbots. However, Whatsapp and iMessage will be following suit very soon and it is my intention to create an app that will allow subscribers to choose what platform they would like to use. This will be the very first of it's kind.

Chatbots really are the future of book marketing and it is important to be ahead of the curve. Current open rates for messages on the Bookbots are upwards of 80% and CTR's are upwards of 50%. Industry standard for email CTR's are in the region of 2%. 

I'll just let that sink in for a moment. 

In order to take the Bots to the next level, I am seeking $10,000 in funding. This will be to allow me to advertise, develop the app and maybe get a nice coffee machine! (Joking, I have a well trained 12-year-old for that.)

In return for your investment you will get in on the ground-floor of something pretty special. There is no doubt that Bob and Bill will continue to grow. As they do, prices for promo slots will go up. I'm offering those who invest opportunities to secure future advertising at incredibly low prices, and lock them in. 

If the entire goal isn't reached, the funds that have been raised will go into advertising and getting as many subscribers on board as possible. (I already have over ten thousand.)

If you aren't able to contribute, please consider spreading the word. Help me help you, by taking the bots to the next level!

story:
Bref résumé

Nous sommes un collectif d'auteurs de la diaspora arabe et berbère du Québec, Canada. Nous sommes prêts à présenter la troisième édition des journées du livre des écrivaines et écrivains issu(e)s du monde arabe. Durant quatre jours, nous présentons une dizaine de conférences sur plusieurs thèmes qui concerne notre communauté.

1. Une conférence sur la présence de l’écriture diasporique dans le paysage littéraire québécois.

2.       Une conférence sur le malaise de la société québécoise vis-à-vis de l’immigration issue des pays arabes.

3.       Une conférence sur l’écriture au féminin au Québec, Canada.

4.       Une conférence sur la représentation de l’immigrant dans la littérature québécoise et canadienne.

5.       Deux rencontres avec des auteur(e)s jeunesse et deux ateliers pour les enfants.

6.        Une grande nuit de la poésie arabe.

Nous vous sollicitons : gens de culture, amoureux de la littérature, promoteurs des arts (mécènes et organismes culturels) et nous comptons sur votre engagement et sur votre générosité afin de permettre aux artistes et aux écrivains de la diaspora de briller dans le ciel du Québec et du Canada.

story:
The Columnist was born in 2014 with the hopes of providing a platform for students to publish their opinions within the Edinburgh community. As a current affairs, culture, social commentary, and opinion magazine, our intention is to promote student opinion and provide alternatives for mainstream student journalism, while maintaining editorial control at a minimum.

In 2016, The Columnist redesigned with a brand new look as we grew our team and continued to publish quality content from University of Edinburgh students. In order to keep our magazine free for our readers, we ask for small donations in support of Issue 7, coming semester 2.

We want to ensure that student voices are heard, and we believe that print publications are still central forums for discussion. We urge you not just to donate but to join us. Comment, rant, draw, write— whatever your talent is, share it with us and with the world.

Welcome to your magazine. 

Read our past issues here: https://issuu.com/columnistmagazine

Additionally, supporters have the opportunity to receive one or both of these original poster designs by The Columnist's illustrator, Vivian Uhlir:

story:
Short Summary

Once upon a time, there were hundreds of Norwegian newspapers in America. On newsstands in local stores and delivered straight to people's mailboxes, these provided a touchstone for immigrants and their descendants. 

Things are different now. Thanks to the internet, Norwegian immigrants in America can keep right on reading their hometown newspapers, and the descendants of those older immigrants are Americans now. Most don't even speak Norwegian! 

So is there still a need for this 128-year-old newspaper, the only (mostly English-language) Norwegian newspaper left from all those hundreds?

We think there is. 

The Norwegian American (formerly the Norwegian American Weekly) has been described as "surprisingly interesting" by readers young and old. It turns out that Norway is a pretty cool country, and we have lots to say about it!

The Norwegian American is moving with the times. In the last three years we've greatly enhanced our digital edition and expanded our presence on Facebook and Twitter (and a little bit Instagram).

Okay, so maybe we're still not quite as with the times as we could be.

At The Norwegian American our focus is on content. Norway is so much more than bunads and lefse (though we still love bunads and lefse!), and we love looking at both the history and the vibrant, modern country the Old Country has become. From Hardanger fiddle to Black Metal; from rømmegrøt to New Nordic cuisine; from Asbjørnsen & Moe's folk tales to Jo Nesbø's latest crime thriller, we bring Norway right to your mailbox. Or to your social media. 

Our paper version is still our best product. The Norwegian American publishes biweekly, 25 issues a year, with news from Norway and the Norwegian-American community, business, sports, opinions, research & science, recipes, events, travel, reviews, comics, crossword puzzles, fiction, language articles, and of course heritage features. Almost all of these features are also available in our digital version.

The newspaper is supported through subscriptions and advertising, but this doesn't quite cover our operating costs. Please consider helping us close the gap by choosing one of the perks below, donating, or by being a subscriber or an advertiser.

 

What We Need

Two years ago, the people in charge of this paper looked at the finances and decided to pull the plug. They're gone now, and we remain, so you can see how well that worked! 

But, okay, the finances are still not great.

Since that time we've cut costs hugely by switching from weekly to biweekly production and moving to a cheaper office just outside Seattle. I'm very pleased to say that our bottom line has gone from $-35K in 2014 to $-21K in 2016. I'm even more pleased to say that this is true despite increasing our wages and benefits paid by $64K! But that still means that we are operating at a loss each year.

Last time we did an Indiegogo campaign we raised over $40K, and that's lasted us this long. If we can raise that much again, I hope to make it last even longer this time... maybe until we achieve self-sufficiency? 

We are moving in the direction of self-sufficiency, but there's also an endless list of things I could spend our increased revenue on. Here is a partial list of the things we'd like to spend money on: 

  • Marketing. The year before we almost stopped publishing, advertising wasn't even a line item. How can you increase subscribership without marketing? Unfortunately the cliché that it takes money to make money is accurate.
  • Payroll. Yes, it's gone up a lot. It still needs to go up more, because not only are the paper's two full-time and two part-time employees grossly underpaid, but we could also really stand to bring on another person or two. I bet we'd sell more advertising if the Advertising Manager position here was a full-time gig! And there are aspects of this business that suffer because we two editors just don't have the time—like social media, the afore-mentioned marketing, and good old-fashioned reporting.
  • Content. We currently get most of our "surprisingly interesting" content for free. Which is amazing! But I have been saying I want to pay all contributors ever since I took over as editor, and I'm ashamed that it still hasn't happened.
  • Travel to Nordic festivals. One of the most effective ways we've found to increase our subscriber base is to physically go where the Norwegian Americans are and shove our papers in their faces. But the financial rewards of doing so are only realized over time—with slim profit margins on our product, it takes a LOT of new subscriptions to pay for a trip to Minot, ND (for example). These trips do double duty because they're also a great source of connections and story ideas and lions and tigers and bears, oh... maybe not those last few.
  • App development. You can already access our online content from any device you choose, but these days anyone who's anyone has an app. And we don't. But we'd like to!

 

What You Get

Holy lutefisk, do we have some great perks on offer!

"Heroes of Ragnarök": First of all, we promise to recognize all of our donors, from $1 up, on our website's Heroes of Ragnarök page. In Norse mythology, Ragnarök is the apocalypse. There are natural disasters, and wars, and many of the gods and goddesses die. But after it's all over, the world is refreshed, ready to grow back better than ever. We survived an apocalypse two years ago, and we're stronger than before. But we still need heroes like you in order to keep doing our work.

Nils Anders Magnet-backed notepad (in multiple packages; $7): See the little guy above? He's sort of our mascot, a hidden person who's looking for his lost family. He really hates it when he can't find a piece of paper to write shopping lists and love notes on, so he's here to help! We don't have an image of the actual item yet, because we won't be ordering them until the campaign closes, but we're going to make it look something like the image on the right. It sort of looks like Nils Anders is in jail! I wonder what he's done?

Want to learn more about Nils Anders? Start here.

Nils Anders shot glass (in multiple packages; $8): If drinking is more your thing than shopping lists and love letters—or if you simply find that one helps make the others more fun—we've got the glasses for you! These tall shot glasses will go perfectly with your aquavit (or other booze or even espresso). The image above is an approximation, because these haven't been ordered yet either.

 

Waffle bandana (in multiple packages; $25): These incredible bandanas are only available through this campaign. Designed exclusively for The Norwegian American by Kristin Derby and produced by Hovden Formal Farm Wear, these look good enough to eat! Available in the four colors shown: classic black, Norwegian blue and red, and a vaguely waffle-toned cream. 

A Taste of Norway: Flavors from The Norwegian American cookbook (in multiple packages; $29): By popular demand, we're bringing you a collection of recipes that have been featured on the pages of The Norwegian American. With over 50 recipes from such acclaimed Nordic food writers as Daytona Strong, Sunny Gandara, Maria Stordahl Nelson, and this paper's own former editor, Christy Olsen Field, the spiral-bound cookbook will cover main courses, soups and sides, and of course sweets. It even has a few drink recipes!  

Old Ballard aquavit club ($250): Our friends at Old Ballard Liquor Co. have offered this amazing perk to Seattle locals: one bottle of aquavit each quarter plus two at Christmas (six total)! You get Älskar (a citron aquavit designed to pair with oysters), Midsommar (a rich, woodsy, and flavorful dill aquavit), Skogen (aquavit flavored with freshly harvested Sitka Spruce tips), Riktig (a classic Norwegian-style aquavit), Tomten (a juletide aquavit made specifically for Glögg), and Ragnarok (a 120-proof dark aquavit for hardcore vikings). For more info on Old Ballard, visit their website. **Please note that this perk does not ship. LOCAL PICKUP ONLY!**

 

Aquavit pairing dinner for six ($1000): Join the Old Ballard Liquor Co. for an exclusive six-course aquavit pairing dinner for six featuring contemporary Northwest Nordic cuisine and a variety of domestic and imported aquavits to try. These private dinners are available exclusively through contributions to organizations like The Norwegian American and are not offered for purchase any other way. It promises to be a once-in-a-lifetime dinner! Locally sourced, seasonal dishes will showcase the amazing bounty of the Pacific Northwest as seen through the eyes of Scandinavian cooking traditions. For more info on Old Ballard, visit their website. **Dinner will be scheduled with OBLC and will take place in Seattle**

 

One-year digital subscription ($30): You get one year's access to all the content on www.norwegianamerican.com (don't worry; it's mostly in English!). This includes all the articles published in the print edition of the newspaper and occasional web-only features. It does not include things like Nyheter fra Norge, letters to the editor, crossword puzzles, folk tales from Tuss og Troll, items on the Bulletin Board, or anything else that doesn't easily lend itself to blogification. 

But that's why we still love our... 

 

One-year print subscription (in multiple packages; $70*): The newspaper is a 24-page tabloid, with larger special issues approximately once a month. One page is fully Norwegian, with news from Norway, and bilingual content is often featured. The standard sections are news, business, sports, opinion, food, travel, research & science, arts & entertainment, norsk språk, and features with a slant toward Norwegian heritage and local Norwegian-American happenings throughout the U.S. Special issues focus on topics of interest to the community, from education and travel to clean energy and alcohol, with, of course, celebration of major holidays like Easter, Syttende Mai, and Christmas.

Print subscriptions also include digital access, if you provide an email address.

*$70 for U.S. addresses, $94 for Canada, and $212 for Norway and all other countries. The difference will be added in shipping when you select these perks.

 

Community Connections ad (in "Newsprint Connections"; $50 value): You don't have to be a nisse to use our Community Connections ads—they're perfect to mark a birthday, anniversary, graduation, or other milestone. These black and white ads are approximately 5x3.5” and can include a photo and a few lines of message. You’ll work with The Norwegian American to design the greeting at least one month prior to placement (within the next year, please).

 

Business card ads (black and white $39 value each; color $57 value each): You send us a digital version of your business card and we print it in the paper—what could be easier? Please note that this offer is for landscape business cards only and that they will print slightly smaller than actual size.

 

Norwegian postcard fiction ($26): Editor Emily C. Skaftun does this really weird thing: she writes approximately 100-word fiction (usually science fiction or fantasy) stories inspired by postcards on the postcards themselves. Then, if you select this perk, she mails it to you! She has 15 postcards from Norway in her stash, and one might have your name on it...

But if you get a weird postcard in the mail in a couple months, remember this moment, because it very likely won't have your name on it.

 

Set of 20 vintage postcards ($27): When we first found these vintage Norwegian postcards hiding away in our old office, we didn’t know where they came from—or really anything about them—but we knew we had exactly seven sets, and we decided to share them with you through our campaign. Well as it turns out, there’s a lot more where that came from!

Postcard enthusiast Esther Van Noy had these lovely postcards made from enhanced versions of antiques she collected over the course of decades. Most of these were originally sent over a century ago from people in Norway to their relatives who had immigrated to America. The lithographs and hand-tinted photographs depict the life and culture of Oslo, Bergen, Trondheim, and Lofoten.

 

Scandinavian Hour ads ($125): Be a part of the Seattle-area institution known as the Scandinavian Hour. This package is for three 105-word ads to be aired on the show, worth $50 each. You write them or work with Doug Warne, the show's host.

Want to be more involved? See the next perk!

 

DJ for a day ($150): Who's a Radio Star? You are! Co-host the Seattle-area KKNW Scandinavian Hour with Doug Warne. Write and present an ad for your company or club fundraiser, introduce a few records, and chat a bit on air! The show records on weekdays and airs on Saturday mornings. To learn more, visit the Scandinavian Hour's website.

 

Two Nights in Skoppum ($250): Contributor David Burke has generously donated a two-night stay in his bed & breakfast, complete with organic breakfasts. Apparently there are goats! To learn more about the B&B, visit The Goats' Garden's website and (for great photos of the property, hot tub, and goats) Airbnb listing.

 

The Impact

Your contribution will help this piece of history keep going. Check out how far we've come in just a few short years, from the early days after the Western Viking/Norway Times merger, through various experiments with mastheads and newsy front pages, to today's sleeker The Norwegian American:

​

Now imagine how far we can go!

 

Risks & Challenges

Risks & challenges? That's all we've got!

At the end of the day, we're still a newspaper in 2017. We strongly believe there's a way forward for niche publications like ours, but the numbers for newspapers are sobering. If we can't survive until we make the leap to digital—and many of our loyal readers are not ready for us to make that leap—then we still might not make it.

I don't want to minimize the risk, but I think it's important to look at how far we've come toward sustainability—we were losing $35K in 2014 and last year it was only $21K, and that's after increasing payroll expenses by $64K! Not only that, but the two big cost-cutting measures we took last year (going biweekly and moving to a cheaper office space) took place in May and July—so we have still not seen a full year of financials reflecting the new reality. We are so close!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help in a more conventional way?

  • To advertise in The Norwegian American, email ads@na-weekly.com. We have many options for print, digital, and social media ads.
  • To become a part of the team—writer, photographer, etc.—write to the editor at emily@na-weekly.com. Please note that we don't pay at this time. See above.

You want to help, but you just don't have any money to spare? You can help us by:

  • Spreading the word about this campaign—the number of shares a campaign has on social media affects how many people it gets shown to. Please boost our signal!
  • Following us on social media: the newspaper is on Facebook at www.facebook.com/naweekly and Twitter as @NAWeekly; Nils Anders Wik is on Instagram and Twitter as @NAWnisse.
  • Visiting our digital edition at www.norwegianamerican.com. You can read up to three articles there for free. If you like them, please share on social media!
  • Signing up for our mailing list using the form on the left side of our website (www.norwegianamerican.com.
  • Asking about The Norwegian American in your local Nordic store, library, or Nordic organization. If they'd like to carry copies of the paper for distribution, have them write us at naw@na-weekly.com.

Tusen takk (thank you) for making it this far!

 

Special thanks to Ingrid's Scandinavian Food in Oregon City for letting us film in the café, to Ingvill Montgomery for being the cutest nisse ever and letting us use her house for filming, and to Derek Willis, who did the filming and editing!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Once upon a time, there were hundreds of Norwegian newspapers in America. On newsstands in local stores and delivered straight to people's mailboxes, these provided a touchstone for immigrants and their descendants. 
Things are different now. Thanks to the internet, Norwegian immigrants in America can keep right on reading their hometown newspapers, and the descendants of those older immigrants are Americans now. Most don't even speak Norwegian! 
So is there still a need for this 128-year-old newspaper, the only (mostly English-language) Norwegian newspaper left from all those hundreds?
We think there is. 
The Norwegian American (formerly the Norwegian American Weekly) has been described as "surprisingly interesting" by readers young and old. It turns out that Norway is a pretty cool country, and we have lots to say about it!
The Norwegian American is moving with the times. In the last three years we've greatly enhanced our digital edition and expanded our presence on Facebook and Twitter (and a little bit Instagram).
Okay, so maybe we're still not quite as with the times as we could be.
At The Norwegian American our focus is on content. Norway is so much more than bunads and lefse (though we still love bunads and lefse!), and we love looking at both the history and the vibrant, modern country the Old Country has become. From Hardanger fiddle to Black Metal; from rømmegrøt to New Nordic cuisine; from Asbjørnsen & Moe's folk tales to Jo Nesbø's latest crime thriller, we bring Norway right to your mailbox. Or to your social media. 
Our paper version is still our best product. The Norwegian American publishes biweekly, 25 issues a year, with news from Norway and the Norwegian-American community, business, sports, opinions, research & science, recipes, events, travel, reviews, comics, crossword puzzles, fiction, language articles, and of course heritage features. Almost all of these features are also available in our digital version.
The newspaper is supported through subscriptions and advertising, but this doesn't quite cover our operating costs. Please consider helping us close the gap by choosing one of the perks below, donating, or by being a subscriber or an advertiser.
 

What We Need
Two years ago, the people in charge of this paper looked at the finances and decided to pull the plug. They're gone now, and we remain, so you can see how well that worked! 
But, okay, the finances are still not great.
Since that time we've cut costs hugely by switching from weekly to biweekly production and moving to a cheaper office just outside Seattle. I'm very pleased to say that our bottom line has gone from $-35K in 2014 to $-21K in 2016. I'm even more pleased to say that this is true despite increasing our wages and benefits paid by $64K! But that still means that we are operating at a loss each year.
Last time we did an Indiegogo campaign we raised over $40K, and that's lasted us this long. If we can raise that much again, I hope to make it last even longer this time... maybe until we achieve self-sufficiency? 
We are moving in the direction of self-sufficiency, but there's also an endless list of things I could spend our increased revenue on. Here is a partial list of the things we'd like to spend money on: 


Marketing. The year before we almost stopped publishing, advertising wasn't even a line item. How can you increase subscribership without marketing? Unfortunately the cliché that it takes money to make money is accurate.

Payroll. Yes, it's gone up a lot. It still needs to go up more, because not only are the paper's two full-time and two part-time employees grossly underpaid, but we could also really stand to bring on another person or two. I bet we'd sell more advertising if the Advertising Manager position here was a full-time gig! And there are aspects of this business that suffer because we two editors just don't have the time—like social media, the afore-mentioned marketing, and good old-fashioned reporting.

Content. We currently get most of our "surprisingly interesting" content for free. Which is amazing! But I have been saying I want to pay all contributors ever since I took over as editor, and I'm ashamed that it still hasn't happened.

Travel to Nordic festivals. One of the most effective ways we've found to increase our subscriber base is to physically go where the Norwegian Americans are and shove our papers in their faces. But the financial rewards of doing so are only realized over time—with slim profit margins on our product, it takes a LOT of new subscriptions to pay for a trip to Minot, ND (for example). These trips do double duty because they're also a great source of connections and story ideas and lions and tigers and bears, oh... maybe not those last few.

App development. You can already access our online content from any device you choose, but these days anyone who's anyone has an app. And we don't. But we'd like to!

 
What You Get
Holy lutefisk, do we have some great perks on offer!
"Heroes of Ragnarök": First of all, we promise to recognize all of our donors, from $1 up, on our website's Heroes of Ragnarök page. In Norse mythology, Ragnarök is the apocalypse. There are natural disasters, and wars, and many of the gods and goddesses die. But after it's all over, the world is refreshed, ready to grow back better than ever. We survived an apocalypse two years ago, and we're stronger than before. But we still need heroes like you in order to keep doing our work.

Nils Anders Magnet-backed notepad (in multiple packages; $7): See the little guy above? He's sort of our mascot, a hidden person who's looking for his lost family. He really hates it when he can't find a piece of paper to write shopping lists and love notes on, so he's here to help! We don't have an image of the actual item yet, because we won't be ordering them until the campaign closes, but we're going to make it look something like the image on the right. It sort of looks like Nils Anders is in jail! I wonder what he's done?
Want to learn more about Nils Anders? Start here.

Nils Anders shot glass (in multiple packages; $8): If drinking is more your thing than shopping lists and love letters—or if you simply find that one helps make the others more fun—we've got the glasses for you! These tall shot glasses will go perfectly with your aquavit (or other booze or even espresso). The image above is an approximation, because these haven't been ordered yet either.
 

Waffle bandana (in multiple packages; $25): These incredible bandanas are only available through this campaign. Designed exclusively for The Norwegian American by Kristin Derby and produced by Hovden Formal Farm Wear, these look good enough to eat! Available in the four colors shown: classic black, Norwegian blue and red, and a vaguely waffle-toned cream. 

A Taste of Norway: Flavors from The Norwegian American cookbook (in multiple packages; $29): By popular demand, we're bringing you a collection of recipes that have been featured on the pages of The Norwegian American. With over 50 recipes from such acclaimed Nordic food writers as Daytona Strong, Sunny Gandara, Maria Stordahl Nelson, and this paper's own former editor, Christy Olsen Field, the spiral-bound cookbook will cover main courses, soups and sides, and of course sweets. It even has a few drink recipes!  

Old Ballard aquavit club ($250): Our friends at Old Ballard Liquor Co. have offered this amazing perk to Seattle locals: one bottle of aquavit each quarter plus two at Christmas (six total)! You get Älskar (a citron aquavit designed to pair with oysters), Midsommar (a rich, woodsy, and flavorful dill aquavit), Skogen (aquavit flavored with freshly harvested Sitka Spruce tips), Riktig (a classic Norwegian-style aquavit), Tomten (a juletide aquavit made specifically for Glögg), and Ragnarok (a 120-proof dark aquavit for hardcore vikings). For more info on Old Ballard, visit their website. **Please note that this perk does not ship. LOCAL PICKUP ONLY!**
 

Aquavit pairing dinner for six ($1000): Join the Old Ballard Liquor Co. for an exclusive six-course aquavit pairing dinner for six featuring contemporary Northwest Nordic cuisine and a variety of domestic and imported aquavits to try. These private dinners are available exclusively through contributions to organizations like The Norwegian American and are not offered for purchase any other way. It promises to be a once-in-a-lifetime dinner! Locally sourced, seasonal dishes will showcase the amazing bounty of the Pacific Northwest as seen through the eyes of Scandinavian cooking traditions. For more info on Old Ballard, visit their website. **Dinner will be scheduled with OBLC and will take place in Seattle**
 
One-year digital subscription ($30): You get one year's access to all the content on www.norwegianamerican.com (don't worry; it's mostly in English!). This includes all the articles published in the print edition of the newspaper and occasional web-only features. It does not include things like Nyheter fra Norge, letters to the editor, crossword puzzles, folk tales from Tuss og Troll, items on the Bulletin Board, or anything else that doesn't easily lend itself to blogification. 
But that's why we still love our...
